Symptoms: Leaf Lesions: The most common and recognizable symptom is the appearance of dark, olive-green to black lesions on the leaves. These lesions are often irregularly shaped and have a velvety or scaly texture. As the disease progresses, the lesions may coalesce, leading to extensive damage to the leaf surface.  Fruit Lesions: Scab also affects apple fruit. Infected fruit develop small, circular or irregularly shaped lesions with a rough, scabby appearance. The color of the lesions varies from olive-green to dark brown or black. As the fruit matures, the scabby lesions may become more prominent and affect the overall appearance of the fruit.  Twig Lesions: While less common, apple scab can also cause small, elongated lesions on young twigs. These lesions may not be as obvious as those on the leaves and fruit, but they can contribute to the spread of the disease.  Leaf Deformation: Severe infections of apple scab on leaves can lead to distortion and curling of the foliage, affecting the tree's overall health and vigor.  Premature Leaf Drop: The disease can cause infected leaves to drop prematurely from the tree, reducing the photosynthetic capacity and potentially weakening the tree over time.
Cause: Apple scab is typically spread through airborne spores produced by the fungus. The primary sources of infection are fallen leaves and infected fruit left on the ground from the previous growing season. In spring, when the conditions are favorable for the fungus to grow, the spores are released and can infect new leaves and fruit.
Prevention: While it's challenging to completely cure apple scab once a tree is infected, it can be managed and controlled with a combination of cultural practices and fungicide applications. Here are some strategies to control apple scab:  Sanitation: Rake up and remove fallen leaves and fruit from around the apple tree. This helps reduce the primary source of infection for the following year. Pruning: Properly prune the apple tree to improve air circulation within the canopy, which reduces the humidity and dampness that favor disease development. Resistant varieties: Plant apple tree varieties that are less susceptible to scab infection. Consult with local horticulturists or agricultural extension offices for suitable varieties in your region. Fungicides: In commercial orchards or severe cases, applying fungicides can be an effective way to control scab. Fungicides need to be applied preventatively, starting in early spring when the buds begin to swell and continuing at regular intervals during wet and humid periods. Organic alternatives: Some organic fungicides, such as neem oil and copper-based sprays, can be used to manage apple scab. They may require more frequent applications than synthetic fungicides.

Symptoms: The symptoms of apple black rot can vary depending on the affected plant parts and the stage of the disease. Common symptoms include:  Fruit Lesions: Infected apples develop circular or elongated lesions with distinct margins. Initially, the lesions are brown or black, and as the disease progresses, they become sunken and may have concentric rings, giving the fruit a "frog-eye" appearance.  Shoot Blight: Young shoots and small branches may exhibit cankers, which are sunken, dark areas on the bark. These cankers can lead to dieback of the affected shoots.  Leaf Symptoms: In some cases, black rot can cause dark, irregularly shaped lesions on the leaves, often accompanied by yellowing and premature leaf drop.  Mummified Fruit: Infected fruit may become mummified, becoming shriveled and dry on the tree or remaining attached throughout the winter.
Cause: The black rot fungus survives in infected plant debris, such as dead leaves and fruit left on the ground or remaining on the tree. In spring, the fungus produces spores that are spread by rain, wind, or insects to new plant tissue, infecting young shoots, fruit, and branches. Warm and wet conditions during the growing season favor the development and spread of the disease.
Prevention: Apple black rot can be challenging to cure once established, but several management practices can help prevent and control the disease:  Sanitation: Remove and destroy infected plant debris, including fallen leaves and mummified fruit. This reduces the primary source of inoculum for the next growing season.  Pruning: Prune and remove infected branches and shoots during dormancy to limit the spread of the disease within the tree.  Fungicides: Apply fungicides preventatively during the growing season to protect susceptible plant tissues from infection. Copper-based fungicides and other fungicides labeled for apple black rot can be effective if applied according to the manufacturer's instructions.  Resistant Varieties: Consider planting apple varieties that show some resistance to black rot to reduce the risk of infection.  Proper Watering: Avoid overhead watering and provide good air circulation to reduce humidity and create an environment less favorable for the black rot fungus.

Symptoms: On Apple and Crabapple Trees:  Yellow Spots: In the early stages, small, bright yellow spots appear on the upper surface of the leaves. Orange Spore Pustules: As the disease progresses, these yellow spots develop into raised, orange or rust-colored spore-filled pustules on the undersides of the leaves. Leaf Curling: Infected leaves may curl, distort, or become dwarfed due to the presence of the pustules. On Eastern Red Cedar or Juniper Hosts:  Gall Formation: The fungus forms small, brown, woody galls on the branches of the Eastern red cedar or Juniper. These galls have a distinctive appearance and are often referred to as "cedar apples" or "cedar galls." Spore Production: During wet conditions, the galls release orange, gelatinous spore horns from the galls, which are then carried by the wind to infect apple trees.
Cause: The Cedar Apple Rust fungus produces spores on the Eastern red cedar or Juniper host during the spring, which are then carried by wind to infect apple or crabapple trees. The disease cycle continues as the fungus produces spores on the apple trees, which are carried back to the juniper host. The disease thrives in regions where both apple trees and Eastern red cedars or Junipers coexist.
Prevention: Controlling Cedar Apple Rust involves several strategies to break the disease cycle and reduce its impact:  Sanitation: Remove and destroy any cedar galls from infected Juniper hosts during the winter or early spring before they release spores. This helps reduce spore production and subsequent infections on apple trees.  Planting Distance: If possible, avoid planting apple trees near Eastern red cedar or Juniper hosts to reduce the chances of disease spread.  Fungicides: Applying fungicides to apple trees during the spring when the rust symptoms first appear can help prevent infection. Fungicides should be applied preventatively and according to the manufacturer's instructions.  Resistant Varieties: Some apple tree varieties are less susceptible to Cedar Apple Rust. Planting resistant cultivars can be an effective preventive measure.  Pruning: Prune infected branches and leaves from apple trees during the growing season to reduce disease pressure.

Symptoms: Symptoms of cherry powdery mildew usually appear on the leaves, but other plant parts, such as blossoms and fruit, can also be affected. Common symptoms include:  White Powdery Coating: The most apparent symptom is the development of a white, powdery coating on the upper surfaces of the leaves. This powdery growth consists of fungal spores and mycelium.  Curling and Distortion: Infected leaves may exhibit curling, rolling, or distortion due to the fungal growth affecting leaf development.  Yellowing: As the disease progresses, infected leaves may turn yellow, which can lead to premature leaf drop.  Blossom and Fruit Infection: In severe cases, the fungus can infect cherry blossoms, leading to poor fruit set. It can also affect the fruit directly, causing blemishes and reducing fruit quality.
Cause: Cherry powdery mildew spreads through airborne spores produced by the fungus. The disease is favored by moderate temperatures and high humidity, making it more prevalent during the spring and early summer when the weather is conducive to fungal growth.
Prevention: While it is challenging to completely cure powdery mildew once it has established itself on cherry trees, the disease can be managed through various preventive and control measures:  Plant Resistant Varieties: Consider planting cherry tree varieties that have shown some resistance to powdery mildew to reduce the risk of infection.  Pruning: Prune cherry trees to improve air circulation within the canopy, which helps reduce humidity levels and create an environment less favorable for fungal growth.  Watering: Avoid overhead watering and irrigate at the base of the tree to keep the foliage dry and minimize conditions that favor powdery mildew development.  Fungicides: In severe cases or when the disease is likely to be problematic, fungicides can be applied preventatively to protect the cherry tree from infection. Consult with local gardening experts or agricultural extension offices for appropriate fungicides and application timings.  Remove Infected Leaves and Prunings: Remove and dispose of infected leaves and prunings away from the cherry trees to minimize the chances of reinfection.

Hindi_name: मक्के की पत्तियों के भूरे  धब्बे
Symptoms: Symptoms of Cercospora leaf spot usually appear on the lower leaves of the corn plant. They start as small, light tan to grayish lesions that later develop into irregular, elongated spots with a dark brown to purplish-brown border. The center of the lesions may become grayish-white or tan with age, hence the name "leaf spot." As the disease progresses, the lesions may coalesce, leading to extensive damage and defoliation of the lower leaves.
Cause: Cercospora leaf spot is caused by the fungus Cercospora zeae-maydis. The fungus overwinters in crop debris and can also survive on infected seeds, facilitating its spread to new plantings in the following growing season.
Prevention: While complete cure of Cercospora leaf spot is challenging once it has established itself in the field, several management practices can help control the disease:  Crop Rotation: Rotate corn with non-host crops (plants not susceptible to Cercospora leaf spot) to reduce the buildup of the pathogen in the soil.  Resistant Varieties: Plant corn hybrids that have shown resistance or tolerance to Cercospora leaf spot. Consult with local agricultural experts or seed suppliers to select appropriate varieties.  Sanitation: Clean and remove crop debris from the field after harvest to reduce the source of inoculum for the next growing season.  Fungicides: Apply fungicides when the disease is first detected and conditions are favorable for disease development. Fungicides should be used preventatively and according to the manufacturer's recommendations.  Timing of Irrigation: Avoid overhead irrigation and irrigate early in the day to allow the leaves to dry quickly, reducing the period of leaf wetness that favors fungal growth.

Symptoms: Symptoms of common rust typically appear on the leaves of the corn plant. They include:  Small, Circular Lesions: The initial symptoms consist of small, oval to elongated, reddish-brown to orange lesions on the upper leaf surface.  Pustules: As the disease progresses, the lesions develop into raised, blister-like structures known as pustules. These pustules rupture to release masses of reddish-brown to black spores.  Rust Color: The abundance of spores gives the affected areas a rusty or dusty appearance, hence the name "common rust."  Leaf Yellowing: Severe infections can lead to extensive pustule formation, which may cause yellowing of the leaves and reduced photosynthetic capacity.
Cause: Common rust is caused by the fungus Puccinia sorghi. The fungus overwinters on infected corn debris or on alternate host plants. In the spring, fungal spores are produced and spread by wind to infect new corn plants, starting the disease cycle for the season.
Prevention: While it is challenging to completely cure common rust once it has infected the corn plants, several management practices can help control the disease:  Resistant Varieties: Plant corn hybrids that have demonstrated resistance or tolerance to common rust. Resistant varieties can significantly reduce the impact of the disease.  Crop Rotation: Rotate corn with non-host crops to reduce the buildup of the pathogen in the soil.  Timely Planting: Early planting may allow corn to establish and grow ahead of peak disease pressure.  Fungicides: In severe cases or when the disease is likely to be problematic, fungicides can be applied preventatively to protect the corn crop from infection. Consult with local agricultural experts or extension offices for appropriate fungicides and application timings.  Sanitation: Remove and destroy crop debris after harvest to reduce the overwintering of the fungus.

Hindi_name: मक्के की उत्तरी पत्ती का झुलसा रोग
Symptoms: Symptoms of Northern Leaf Blight primarily appear on the leaves of the corn plant. They include:  Long, Elliptical Lesions: The initial symptoms consist of long, elliptical lesions that run parallel to the leaf veins. The lesions are tan to grayish-brown and may have wavy edges.  Lesion Expansion: As the disease progresses, the lesions elongate and become more pronounced, covering significant portions of the leaf surface.  Lesion Coalescence: Severe infections can lead to the coalescence of lesions, resulting in large, irregularly shaped areas of blighted tissue.  Leaf Dieback: Advanced infections can cause the affected leaves to die prematurely, leading to reduced photosynthesis and potential yield loss.
Cause: Northern Leaf Blight is caused by the fungus Exserohilum turcicum. The fungus overwinters in infected corn debris or on alternate host plants. In the spring, when conditions are favorable, the spores are released and spread by wind or rain to infect new corn plants.
Prevention: While it is challenging to completely cure Northern Leaf Blight once it has infected the corn plants, several management practices can help control the disease:  Resistant Varieties: Plant corn hybrids that have demonstrated resistance or tolerance to Northern Leaf Blight. Resistant varieties can significantly reduce the impact of the disease.  Crop Rotation: Rotate corn with non-host crops to reduce the buildup of the pathogen in the soil.  Timely Planting: Early planting may allow corn to establish and grow ahead of peak disease pressure.  Fungicides: In severe cases or when the disease is likely to be problematic, fungicides can be applied preventatively to protect the corn crop from infection. Consult with local agricultural experts or extension offices for appropriate fungicides and application timings.  Sanitation: Remove and destroy crop debris after harvest to reduce the overwintering of the fungus.

Symptoms: Symptoms of black rot primarily appear on grape leaves, berries, and stems. They include:  Leaf Lesions: Early symptoms manifest as small, reddish-brown spots on the upper side of the leaves. As the disease progresses, these spots enlarge, turning brown with distinct yellow halos around the lesions. The centers of the lesions may drop out, giving the leaves a "shot-hole" appearance.  Fruit Infection: Infected grapes develop small, circular, or irregularly shaped lesions with dark brown to black centers. The lesions may also have a yellow halo around them. As the fruit matures, the lesions become sunken and hard, resembling dried, black mummies.  Stem Infection: Infections can also occur on young stems and tendrils, causing dark brown to black lesions with cracked surfaces.  Leaf Curling and Defoliation: Severe infections can lead to leaf curling, wilting, and premature defoliation, weakening the vine and reducing fruit quality and yield.
Cause: Black rot is caused by the fungus Guignardia bidwellii. The fungus overwinters on infected grape canes, fallen leaves, and fruit mummies left on the ground. In the spring, during wet and warm conditions, the fungus produces spores that are spread by rain and wind to infect new grapevine tissues.
Prevention: While it is challenging to completely cure black rot once it has infected the grapevines, several management practices can help control the disease:  Sanitation: Clean up and remove infected plant debris, including fallen leaves and mummified fruit from around the grapevines. This helps reduce the primary source of infection for the following year.  Pruning: Properly prune the grapevines to improve air circulation within the canopy, which reduces humidity and dampness that favor disease development.  Fungicides: In commercial vineyards or severe cases, applying fungicides can be an effective way to control black rot. Fungicides need to be applied preventatively and at specific intervals during the growing season, depending on the weather and disease pressure.  Resistant Varieties: Some grapevine varieties are less susceptible to black rot. Planting resistant cultivars can help reduce the risk of infection.  Organic Alternatives: Some organic fungicides, such as sulfur-based sprays, can be used to manage black rot. They may require more frequent applications than synthetic fungicides.

Symptoms: Esca is characterized by several distinctive symptoms, which can vary depending on the stage of the disease:  Tiger Stripes: One of the most noticeable early symptoms is the appearance of "tiger stripes" on the leaves. These are yellow or reddish-brown streaks between the leaf veins, creating a striped pattern.  Necrosis: The tiger stripes often progress to necrosis, where the tissue between the veins dies, turning brown or black. This necrosis can spread throughout the leaf, eventually causing it to drop prematurely.  Foliar Symptoms: As the disease advances, leaves may show other patterns, such as "fisheye" spots, "esca proper" lesions (circular spots with a reddish-brown center and yellow border), and "taches de vin" (small, dark spots surrounded by a yellow halo).  Trunk Symptoms: Infected grapevines can develop dark streaks on their trunk, often referred to as "black measles," which may be accompanied by gumming or resin exudates.  Fruit Symptoms: In some cases, infected fruit clusters may display "bird's eye" necrosis, where individual berries show circular, dark spots that resemble bird's eyes.
Cause: Esca is caused by several fungi, including Phaeoacremonium spp., Phaeomoniella chlamydospora, and Fomitiporia mediterranea. These fungi are commonly found in vineyards, and infections often occur through pruning wounds or natural openings in the vines. The disease is more likely to affect older vines, although it can impact younger plants as well.
Prevention: Managing Grape Esca is challenging due to its complexity and the limited effectiveness of curative treatments. The disease cannot be completely cured once established, so preventive measures are crucial. Here are some management strategies:  Sanitation: Promptly prune and remove infected wood from the vineyard, especially during the dormant season. This helps reduce the inoculum source for new infections.  Proper Pruning Techniques: Use clean and sharp pruning tools, and avoid pruning during wet weather to minimize infection risk.  Fungicides: Although fungicides have limited efficacy for curing Esca, preventive applications during the growing season may help reduce the spread of the disease. Consult with a viticulturist or agricultural expert for appropriate fungicide recommendations.  Vineyard Health: Maintain overall vineyard health by providing proper irrigation, balanced nutrition, and minimizing stress factors that may make vines more susceptible to Esca.  Use of Resistant Varieties: Some grapevine varieties exhibit partial resistance to Esca. Consider planting these varieties in regions where the disease is prevalent.

Symptoms: Symptoms of Isariopsis Leaf Spot typically appear on grape leaves, but other plant parts, such as stems and fruit, can also be affected. They include:  Small Spots: The disease starts with the development of small, dark spots on the upper surface of the leaves. These spots may be circular or irregularly shaped and have a reddish-brown to purple color.  Spots with Light Centers: As the disease progresses, the center of the spots may become paler, often turning grayish-white or tan, which creates a distinctive "target" appearance.  Leaf Lesions: Over time, the spots may coalesce and expand, leading to the formation of larger lesions on the leaves.  Leaf Yellowing: Infected leaves may exhibit yellowing around the lesions and between the veins, leading to overall leaf discoloration.  Premature Leaf Drop: Severe infections can cause premature defoliation, leading to a weakening of the grapevine and potentially reducing fruit quality and yield.
Cause: Isariopsis Leaf Spot is caused by the fungus Isariopsis spp. The fungus can survive in infected plant debris, such as fallen leaves, and can overwinter in the vineyard. In the spring, fungal spores are released and spread to new plant tissues through rain, wind, or irrigation splashing, initiating new infections.
Prevention: While it is challenging to completely cure Isariopsis Leaf Spot once it has infected the grapevines, several management practices can help control the disease:  Sanitation: Clean up and remove infected plant debris, including fallen leaves, from around the grapevines. This helps reduce the primary source of infection for the following year.  Pruning: Properly prune the grapevines to improve air circulation within the canopy, which reduces humidity and dampness that favor disease development.  Fungicides: In severe cases or when the disease is likely to be problematic, fungicides can be applied preventatively to protect the grapevine from infection. Consult with local agricultural experts or extension offices for appropriate fungicides and application timings.  Resistant Varieties: Some grapevine varieties are less susceptible to Isariopsis Leaf Spot. Planting resistant cultivars can help reduce the risk of infection.  Organic Alternatives: Some organic fungicides, such as copper-based sprays, can be used to manage Isariopsis Leaf Spot. They may require more frequent applications than synthetic fungicides.

Symptoms: HLB symptoms can vary depending on the citrus tree's age, the severity of the infection, and the citrus variety. Common symptoms include:  Yellowing: Yellowing of the leaves, called "chlorosis," is one of the earliest and most distinctive symptoms of HLB. The yellowing typically starts in a mottled pattern, affecting random areas of the canopy.  Asymmetrical Leaf Blotching: HLB-infected leaves often exhibit asymmetrical blotches of yellowing and green on the same leaf, a pattern known as "blotchy mottle."  Vein Yellowing: The veins of the leaves may remain green while the surrounding tissue turns yellow, creating a "green island" effect.  Twisted Growth and Small Fruits: Affected branches may exhibit stunted, twisted, or "witches' broom" growth. The fruits on HLB-infected trees are often small, lopsided, and poorly colored.
Cause: HLB is primarily transmitted by a tiny insect called the Asian citrus psyllid (Diaphorina citri). When the psyllid feeds on an infected citrus tree, it can acquire the bacterium and then transmit it to healthy citrus trees as it feeds on them. Once inside a healthy tree, the bacterium spreads and colonizes the tree's phloem vessels, disrupting the flow of nutrients, water, and sugars throughout the plant. This eventually leads to the decline of the tree and the development of various symptoms.
Prevention: As of now, there is no cure for Citrus Greening, and infected trees will eventually die. Management of the disease focuses on early detection, removal of infected trees, and control of the Asian citrus psyllid population to limit the spread of the disease. Here are some key management strategies:  Early Detection and Removal: Regularly inspect citrus trees for symptoms of HLB. If a tree is confirmed to be infected, it should be removed and properly disposed of to prevent further spread of the disease.  Use of Healthy Plant Material: When planting new citrus trees, use certified disease-free nursery stock to reduce the risk of introducing HLB.  Insect Control: Implement a comprehensive insect control program to manage the Asian citrus psyllid population. This may involve the use of insecticides, beneficial insects, and cultural practices to reduce psyllid infestations.  Quarantine Measures: In regions where HLB is present, implement strict quarantine measures to prevent the movement of infected plant material.  Research and Breeding: Researchers are actively working on developing HLB-resistant citrus varieties through breeding and genetic modification.

Hindi_name: आड़ू का जीवाणु पत्ती धब्बा रोग
Symptoms: Symptoms of Bacterial Spot can appear on various parts of the peach tree, including leaves, fruit, and shoots. They include:  Leaf Lesions: Small, water-soaked lesions initially develop on the upper surface of the leaves. These lesions are often angular and have a dark, reddish-brown color, surrounded by a yellow halo.  Leaf Drop: Severely infected leaves may turn yellow, wilt, and drop prematurely, leading to defoliation, reduced photosynthesis, and overall tree stress.  Fruit Lesions: Infected fruits develop small, circular, raised lesions with dark centers and purplish margins. As the disease progresses, the lesions may coalesce, resulting in larger, irregularly shaped spots on the fruit.  Shoot Cankers: The bacteria can cause small, dark, sunken lesions (cankers) on young shoots and branches, leading to dieback.
Cause: Bacterial Spot is caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas arboricola pv. pruni. The bacterium overwinters in infected plant debris, cankers, or in buds and shoots. In spring, bacterial cells are spread to new growth and leaves through rain splashes, irrigation water, wind, and insects.
Prevention: Currently, there is no cure for Bacterial Spot in infected peach trees, so the focus is on managing and preventing the disease. Here are some management strategies:  Sanitation: Remove and destroy any infected plant material, including fallen leaves, pruned branches, and mummified fruit. This helps reduce the source of inoculum for new infections in the following season.  Pruning: Prune infected branches during the dormant season, making sure to sterilize pruning tools between cuts to prevent further spread of the bacteria.  Copper-Based Sprays: Copper-based bactericides can be applied as preventive treatments during the growing season to protect the tree from infection. These sprays should be used according to the manufacturer's instructions and in combination with other management practices.  Avoid Overhead Watering: Minimize overhead irrigation and avoid wetting the foliage. Watering at the base of the tree helps reduce conditions conducive to bacterial growth and spread.  Resistant Varieties: Consider planting peach tree varieties that have shown some level of resistance to Bacterial Spot.

Hindi_name: शिमला मिर्च का जीवाणु पत्ती धब्बा रोग
Symptoms: Symptoms of Bacterial Spot on bell peppers typically appear on leaves, fruit, and stems. They include:  Leaf Lesions: Small, water-soaked lesions initially develop on the upper surface of the leaves. These lesions are often dark, olive-green, or brown and have a slightly raised appearance.  Leaf Yellowing: The area surrounding the lesions may turn yellow, creating a distinctive halo effect.  Leaf Drop: Severely infected leaves may become distorted, curl, and drop prematurely, leading to defoliation and reduced photosynthesis.  Fruit Lesions: On the fruit, lesions are circular, dark, and slightly raised. As the disease progresses, the lesions may become sunken, giving the fruit a rough appearance.  Fruit Cracking: Infected fruit may develop cracks near the lesions, making them more susceptible to secondary infections and decay.
Cause: Bacterial Spot is caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria. The bacterium can survive in infected plant debris, including crop residues and weed hosts. It is spread through splashing water, rain, irrigation, contaminated tools, and human handling, leading to the rapid spread of the disease.
Prevention: Currently, there is no cure for Bacterial Spot in infected bell pepper plants. The focus is on managing and preventing the disease through various strategies:  Sanitation: Remove and destroy any infected plant material, including infected leaves, stems, and fruit, to reduce the source of inoculum for new infections.  Crop Rotation: Avoid planting peppers and related crops in the same location year after year to reduce the buildup of bacterial populations in the soil.  Resistant Varieties: Consider planting bell pepper varieties that have shown some level of resistance to Bacterial Spot.  Copper-Based Sprays: Copper-based bactericides can be applied as preventive treatments during the growing season to protect the plants from infection. These sprays should be used according to the manufacturer's instructions and in combination with other management practices.  Water Management: Avoid overhead watering and minimize splashing water on the foliage, as it can help spread the bacteria.

Symptoms: This is a common disease of potato occurring on the foliage at any stage of the growth and causes characteristic leaf spots and blight. Normally the disease symptoms become apparent during tuber bulking stage and develop leading to the harvest. The early blight is first observed on the plants as small, black lesions mostly on the older foliage. Spots enlarge, and by the time they are one-fourth inch in diameter or larger, concentric rings in a bull's eye pattern can be seen in the center of the diseased area. Tissue surrounding the spots may turn yellow. If high temperature and humidity occur at this time, much of the foliage is killed. Lesions on the stems are similar to those on leaves, sometimes girdling the plant if they occur near the soil line.
Cause: Potato early blight is caused by a fungus called Alternaria solani.                                                                                                     The fungus survives in infected plant debris or soil and spreads through spores.                                             Factors like warm and humid weather, overcrowding of plants, and poor air circulation can promote the disease.                                                                                                                                                                                                            The fungus attacks potato leaves, causing brown spots with concentric rings. It can reduce crop yield and quality.                                                                                                                                                                                                      Proper crop rotation, removing infected debris, and applying fungicides can help control early blight.
Prevention: Prune or stake plants to improve air circulation and reduce fungal problems. Make sure to disinfect your pruning shears (one part bleach to 4 parts water) after each cut. Keep the soil under plants clean and free of garden debris. Add a layer of organic compost to prevent the spores from splashing back up onto vegetation. Drip irrigation and soaker hoses can be used to help keep the foliage dry. For best control, apply copper-based fungicides early, two weeks before disease normally appears or when weather forecasts predict a long period of wet weather. Alternatively, begin treatment when disease first appears, and repeat every 7-10 days for as long as needed. Containing copper and pyrethrins, Bonide® Garden Dust is a safe, one-step control for many insect attacks and fungal problems. For best results, cover both the tops and undersides of leaves with a thin uniform film or dust. Depending on foliage density, 10 oz will cover 625 sq ft. Repeat applications every 7-10 days, as needed. SERENADE Garden is a broad spectrum, preventative bio-fungicide recommended for the control or suppression of many important plant diseases. For best results, treat prior to foliar disease development or at the first sign of infection. Repeat at 7-day intervals or as needed. Remove and destroy all garden debris after harvest and practice crop rotation the following year. Burn or bag infected plant parts. Do NOT compost.

Symptoms: Small water-soaked spots develop at the tips, margins or any other part of the leaf which enlarge to form irregular dark brown lesions surrounded by a light green halo.  During morning hours, a whitish cottony growth of the fungus is visible around the dark brown lesions on the under surface of the leaves especially when weather remains sufficiently humid or when there is dew fall in the morning hours.                                                                                                                                           In case of infection originating from infected tubers, elongated brown stripes develop on the stem from below the ground level and encircle it.  The lesions also appear on the stem near the growing point when the inoculum of the fungus comes from the infected plants.                                                                                                                                                   Infected tubers show irregular, shallow or sunken reddish brown patches. Inside infected tissue is spongy and rusty brown to varying depths. In sub-mountainous areas, the lesions on tubers are locally called "Pathar Dag". Later on, these lesions are often invaded by secondary pathogens especially in wet soils or in storage resulting into soft rot.  Smaller immature tubers are more prone to infection as compared to the larger ones and rotting is more in heavy wet soils.  Late blight does not spread from tuber to tuber in cold stores.
Cause: The primary source of the disease is infected seed tubers planted after cold storage.  Not all, but a few of the infected tubers give rise to primary sporangial inoculum which further infects the nearby plants creating a primary focus of infection in the field.  Some of the infected tubers do not sprout or are soon killed after sprouting giving patchy appearance in the field.
Prevention: Choose resistant potato varieties: Select potato types that have natural resistance to late blight. These varieties are less likely to get infected and can withstand the disease better.  Rotate crops: Avoid planting potatoes in the same area year after year. Instead, grow non-potato crops in between to disrupt the disease cycle and reduce the number of pathogens in the soil.  Clean up plant debris: Remove and destroy any infected plant parts like leaves, stems, and tubers at the end of the season. This helps eliminate disease-causing spores and prevents them from surviving and spreading.  Use fungicides: Consider applying fungicides to protect your potato plants. These chemicals can help prevent late blight infection. Follow the instructions on the product label to ensure safe and effective use.  By following these measures, you can minimize the risk of late blight and protect your potato crops from this destructive disease.

Symptoms: Powdery white or grayish fungal growth on the leaves, stems, and sometimes fruits of squash plants. Initially, the powdery mildew appears as small spots or patches, which gradually spread and cover larger areas. Infected leaves may become distorted, turn yellow or brown, and eventually die. Severe infections can lead to stunted growth and reduced fruit production.
Cause: Squash powdery mildew is primarily caused by a fungal pathogen called Podosphaera xanthii. This pathogen belongs to a group of fungi known as powdery mildews. It specifically affects various squash plants, including zucchini, pumpkin, and butternut squash.  The fungus thrives in warm and dry conditions, with optimal growth occurring between 60°F and 80°F (15°C to 27°C). It spreads through airborne spores that are easily carried by wind, water, and insects. When these spores land on susceptible plant surfaces, they germinate and form a white or grayish powdery growth.
Prevention: Plant resistant varieties: Choose squash varieties that are known to have resistance to powdery mildew. These varieties are less susceptible to the disease and can withstand infections better.  Proper spacing: Provide adequate spacing between squash plants to improve air circulation. Good airflow helps reduce humidity and prevents the development and spread of powdery mildew.  Watering techniques: Avoid overhead watering, which can promote the growth and spread of fungal spores. Instead, water at the base of the plants using drip irrigation or a soaker hose. Watering in the early morning allows foliage to dry quickly, reducing moisture levels.  Regular inspections: Monitor your squash plants regularly for any signs of powdery mildew. Early detection can help prevent the spread of the disease to other plants. If you notice any infected leaves, remove them immediately and dispose of them properly.  Fungicide applications: In severe cases or when prevention methods are not sufficient, you can consider using fungicides labeled for powdery mildew control. Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the manufacturer for proper application and timing. Remember to consider the pre-harvest interval (PHI) before using any chemical treatments.

Symptoms: Leaf scorch makes strawberry leaves look like they’ve been burnt by something.  Beginning signs of leaf scorch include:  Irregular dark purple or brown spots scattered over leaf surface Appearance of “tar drops” on leaves Spots with purple centers and no defined border (the leaf spot disease has a clear margin) As the disease progresses, the symptoms intensify and look more unsightly:  Large sunken lesions where spots have merged together Purplish to brown colored areas that can girdle leaves from the base Brown, curled up leaves Scorched dying leaves Weakened vigor Dead leaves, flowers, or fruit (in severe infections)
Cause: Fungal infection: Strawberry leaf scorch is caused by a fungus called Diplocarpon earliana. It infects strawberry plants, especially in humid and rainy conditions.  Humidity and moisture: High humidity and wet leaves create a favorable environment for the fungus to grow and spread. Rainy weather or overwatering can contribute to leaf scorch.  Infected plant material: The fungus can survive on fallen leaves or infected runners. If you leave these materials around, the disease can continue to spread to healthy plants.  Susceptible varieties: Some strawberry varieties are more prone to leaf scorch. If you're experiencing frequent outbreaks, consider choosing resistant varieties in the future.  Environmental stress: Weak or stressed plants are more vulnerable to diseases. Factors like drought, heat stress, or poor soil conditions can make plants more susceptible to leaf scorch.
Prevention: While leaf scorch on strawberry plants can be frustrating, there are some strategies which home gardeners may employ to help prevent its spread in the garden. The primary means of strawberry leaf scorch control should always be prevention.                                                                                                                                      Since this fungal pathogen overwinters on the fallen leaves of infected plants, proper garden sanitation is key. This includes the removal of infected garden debris from the strawberry patch, as well as the frequent establishment of new strawberry transplants. The creation of new plantings and strawberry patches is key to maintaining a consistent strawberry harvest, as older plants are more likely to show signs of severe infection.  When making new plantings always ensure that good planting practices are implemented. These practices include the use of proper plant spacing to provide adequate air circulation and the use of drip irrigation. The avoidance of waterlogged soil and frequent garden cleanup will help to reduce the likelihood of spread of this fungus.

Symptoms: Symptoms can be seen on the foliage, stems, and fruits of tomatoes. Initially small yellow-green lesions appear on young leaves for bacterial spot, whilst bacterial speck causes black spots with a narrow yellow halo.                                                                                                                                                                                           They are usually more numerous on leaf margins or tips, which may appear deformed and twisted. In severe cases, the spots of bacterial speck may coalesce or overlap, resulting in larger and irregular lesions. Bacterial spot lesions can enlarge from 0.25 cm to 0.5 cm and become tan to brownish-red, which will eventually look like shot holes when the center dries up. Bacterial spot produces similar lesion of fruits as it does on the leaves and eventually roughen, becoming brown and scabbed. Bacterial speck causes tiny, slightly raised black specks. It is difficult to distinguish between these two diseases at an early stage.
Cause: Bacterial spot of tomato is caused by Xanthomonas vesicatoria, Xanthomonas euvesicatoria, Xanthomonas gardneri, and Xanthomonas perforans.  These bacterial pathogens can be introduced into a garden on contaminated seed and transplants, which may or may not show symptoms.  The pathogens enter plants through natural openings (e.g., stomates), as well as through wounds.  Disease development is favored by warm (75° to 86°F), wet weather.  Wind-driven rain can contribute to more severe disease as the pathogens are splashed and spread to healthy leaves and fruit.  Bacterial spot pathogens can survive well in tomato debris, but they survive very poorly in soil when not associated with debris.
Prevention: Plant pathogen-free seed or transplants to prevent the introduction of bacterial spot pathogens on contaminated seed or seedlings.  If a clean seed source is not available or you suspect that your seed is contaminated, soak seeds in water at 122°F for 25 min. to kill the pathogens.                                                                      To keep leaves dry and to prevent the spread of the pathogens, avoid overhead watering (e.g., with a wand or sprinkler) of established plants and instead use a drip-tape or soaker-hose.  Also to prevent spread, DO NOT handle plants when they are wet (e.g., from dew) and routinely sterilize tools with either 10% bleach solution or (better) 70% alcohol (e.g., rubbing alcohol).  Where bacterial spot has been a recurring problem, consider using preventative applications of copper-based products registered for use on tomato, especially during warm, wet periods.                                                                                        Keep in mind however, that if used excessively or for prolonged periods, copper may no longer control the disease.  Be sure to read and follow all label instructions of the product that you select to ensure that you use it in the safest and most effective manner possible.  Burn, bury or hot compost tomato debris at the end of the season.  Wait at least one year before planting tomatoes in a given location again, and remove and burn, bury or hot compost any volunteer tomatoes that come up in your garden.

Hindi_name: टमाटर में देरी से होने वाली अंगमारी
Symptoms: Brownish-green spots appear on the leaf margins and leaf tops. Later, large areas of the leaves turn brown completely. During wet weather, lesions on the lower side of the leaves may be covered with a gray to white moldy growth, making it easier to distinguish healthy from dead leaf tissue. As the disease progresses, the foliage runs brown, curls and dries. In some cases, the sharply delimited brown spots and the white covering also appear on the stems, branches, and petioles. Greyish-green to dirty-brown and wrinkled stains appear on the fruits. At these spots, the fruit flesh is hardened
Cause: The risk of infection is highest in midsummer. The fungus enters the plant via wounds and rips in the skin. Temperature and moisture are the most important environmental factors affecting the development of the disease. Late blight fungi grow best in high relative humidities (around 90%) and in temperature ranges of 18 to 26°C. Warm and dry summer weather can bring the spread of the disease to a halt
Prevention: Purchase healthy seeds from reliable retailers.                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Plant more resilient varieties.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Tomatoes and potatoes should not be cultivated next to each other.                                                                                                                                                                              Try to keep plants dry through good drainage and ventilation of your cultures.                                                                                                                                            Install a simple transparent rain shelter with the help of a tarpaulin and wooden stakes.                                                                                                                                                                                        Use plant fortifier for general strengthening of the plants.                                                                                                                                                                                              Crop rotation of two to three years with non-host crops is recommended.                                                                                                                                                                         Silicate-containing fertilizers may increase the resistance to the fungus, especially in the seedling stage.                                                                                                                                                                                                              Avoid irrigation late in the day and irrigate plants at ground level.Disinfect field equipment and tools.

Symptoms: Symptoms commonly occur on both sides of the foliage and sometimes on fruit. Older leaves are infected first and then the disease slowly moves up towards young leaves. On the upper leaf surface, small, diffuse, pale green or yellowish spots with indefinite margins appear. On the underside, olive green to grayish purple and velvety patches develop below the leaf spots. These are composed of spore-producing structures and spore masses (conidia). Over time, as the spots enlarge, the color of the infected leaf changes from yellowish (chlorosis) to brown (necrosis) and the leaf begins to curl and dry. The leaves will drop prematurely, leading to defoliation in severe cases. Occasionally, this pathogen causes disease on the blossoms or fruits with various symptoms. The blossoms may turn black and will be killed before fruit set. Green and ripe fruits will develop smooth black irregular area on the stem end. As the disease progresses, the infected area becomes sunken, dry and leathery.
Cause: The symptoms are caused by the fungus Mycovellosiella fulva, whose spores can survive without a host for 6 months to a year at room temperature (non-obligate). Prolonged leaf moisture and humidities above 85% favor the germination of spores. The temperature must be between 4° to 34 °C for spores to germinate, with an optimum temperature at 24-26°C. Dry conditions and the absence of free water on leaves impair germination. The symptoms usually start to appear 10 days after inoculation with the development of spots on both sides of the leaf blade. On the underside, a large number of spore-producing structures are formed and these spores are easily spread from plant to plant by the wind and water splashing, but also on tools, clothing of workers and insects. The pathogen usually infects the leaves by penetrating through stomata in a high humidity level.
Prevention: Use certified, disease-free seeds, plant resistant or resilient varieties if available in your area.                                                                                                          Plant early to reduce the disease severity.                                                                                                                                                                                                    Adjust row and plant spacing to enhance air circulation and reduce humidity in the canopy.                                                                                                             Monitor for disease and rogue infected plants as soon as detected.                                                                                                                                                             Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization.                                                                                                                                                                                                                   Promote air circulation inside the greenhouse.                                                                                                                                                                                                   Keep the relative humidity below 85% and night temperatures higher than outside temperatures (suitable on greenhouse).                                                                                                                                                                                          Use drip irrigation and avoid watering foliage.                                                                                                                                                                                                                Use a stake, strings, or prune the plant to keep it upstanding and  increase airflow in and around it.                                                                                              Remove and destroy (burn) all plants debris after the harvest.                                                                                                                                                                             Sanitize the greenhouse between crops and maintain extensive hygiene standards with tools and among workers

Hindi_name: टमाटर का सेप्टोरिया पत्तों पर धब्बा
Symptoms: Septoria leaf spots start off somewhat circular and first appear on the undersides of older leaves, at the bottom of the plant. They are small, 1/16 to 1/8 inches (1.6 to 3.2 millimeters) in diameter, with a dark brown margin and lighter gray or tan centers. A yellow halo may surround the spot.  As the disease develops, the spots will get larger and may merge. If you view them through a magnifying lens you may see the fruiting bodies of the fungus, which look like dark brown pimples. This is one of the symptoms that distinguish Septoria leaf spot from other leaf-spotting diseases.​  Although the symptoms usually occur in the older, lower leaves, the disease can develop at any stage in the tomato plant's life.1 They may also appear on the stems as well as the blossoms and calyxes. One small bit of good news—they rarely affect the fruits.  If untreated, Septoria leaf spot will cause the leaves to turn yellow and eventually dry out and fall off. This will weaken the plant, send it into decline, and cause sun scalding of the unprotected, exposed tomatoes. Without leaves, the plant will not continue producing and maturing tomatoes. Septoria leaf spot spreads rapidly.
Cause: Fungal infection: Tomato septoria leaf spot is caused by the fungus Septoria lycopersici. It commonly affects tomato plants, particularly in warm and humid conditions.  Spread: The fungus spreads through water splashes, rain, or irrigation. It can also be carried on tools, equipment, or hands, which come into contact with infected plants.  Infected plant debris: The fungus can overwinter on infected plant debris, such as fallen leaves or stems. If these materials are not removed and properly disposed of, the disease can persist and spread to healthy plants in subsequent seasons.
Prevention: First, remove all fallen plant debris from your garden beds. Fallen leaves can harbor spores and allow them to overwinter. Be sure to clean your hands and sterilize tools you use to remove debris if you suspect fungal disease may be present.  Keep weeds in check. This is especially true with septoria lycopersici. Many solanaceous weeds can harbor fungal spores. Diseased weeds will spread the disease to nearby plants.  Mulch around your plants. This has a dual effect. It prevents soil splashing up onto the leaves, which can spread spores to your plant. It also reduces the likelihood of weed development. A 3″ to 4″ layer of mulch will also aid in water retention in the soil, which is an added bonus!  Water the soil, not the plants. Drip or soaker hose irrigation will reduce the likelihood of spore spread.  Rotate crops. Septoria fungi can survive in diseased plant debris, weeds, or perennials for up to 3 years. Crop rotation can reduce the likelihood of reinfection year after year.  Ensure there’s proper airflow. Plants which are tightly packed together are more at risk from diseases. Trimming excess foliage will provide better airflow. It also reduces the ease of spore spread, as leaves are spaced further apart. Staking plants or securing them in sturdy tomato cages can help with airflow as well.  Keep pests at bay. Remember, pests may accidentally carry spores from plant to plant. Reducing your pest population will also reduce spore transmission.

Hindi_name: टमाटर की पत्ती मोड़ने वाला पीला विषाणु (येल्लो लीफ़ कर्ल वायरस)
Symptoms: Infection at seedling stage results in  severe stunting of young leaves and shoots, leading to a somewhat bushy growth of the plant. In older plants, the infection results in excessive branching, thicker and wrinkled leaves, and interveinal chlorosis clearly visible on the leaf blade. At later stages of the disease, the plants take a leathery texture and their chlorotic margins are rolled upwards and inwards. If the infection takes place before the flowering stage, the number of fruits is considerably reduced, even though there are no noticeable symptoms on their surface.
Cause: TYLCV is not seed-borne and is not transmitted mechanically. It is spread by whiteflies of the Bemisia tabaci species. These whiteflies feed on the lower leaf surface of a number of plants and are attracted by young tender plants. The whole infection cycle can take place in about 24 hours and is favored by dry weather with high temperatures.
Prevention: Use resistant or tolerant varieties. Plant early to avoid peak populations of the whitefly.  Intercrop with rows of non-susceptible plants such as squash and cucumber.  Use nets to cover seedbeds and prevent whiteflies from  reaching plants.  Practice crop rotation with non-susceptible plants.  Mulch the seedbed or the field to break the life cycle of the whitefly.  Use sticky yellow plastic traps to mass-catch the insect.  Monitor the field, handpick diseased plants and bury them away from the field.  Find and eradicate weeds in and around the field.  Plow deep all plant debris after harvest or burn them.

Symptoms: Early infection may cause plants to look yellow and generally stunted. Dark and light green leaves mottling. There may be twisted, deformed, or diminished leaves. At warm temperatures, certain cultivars may show signs of dead leaf tissue. Possible uneven ripening of fruits. Decreased total fruit yield and average fruit size. Fruit with irregular, off-color spots that can be either elevated or depressed. Fruits may exhibit browning just beneath the skin (brownwall).
Cause: Viral infection: Tomato mosaic virus (TMV) is caused by a virus that infects tomato plants. It can also affect other plants in the Solanaceae family, such as peppers and eggplants.  Transmission: The virus spreads through direct contact with infected plants, contaminated tools, or hands. It can also be carried by insects, such as aphids and whiteflies, which feed on infected plants and then transfer the virus to healthy ones.  Contaminated seeds: TMV can be present in infected tomato seeds, leading to the transmission of the virus to new plants during germination and growth.
Prevention: Use virus-free seeds: Purchase certified disease-free tomato seeds from reputable suppliers to minimize the risk of introducing the virus into your crops.  Practice strict hygiene: Clean and sanitize tools, equipment, and hands before handling tomato plants. This helps prevent the spread of the virus between plants.  Control insect vectors: Implement measures to control aphids, whiteflies, and other insects that can transmit the virus. This may include using insecticidal soaps or natural predators to manage their populations.  Remove infected plants: If you notice any plants showing symptoms of TMV, such as mosaic-like patterns on leaves or stunted growth, remove them immediately to prevent the spread of the virus to healthy plants.  Minimize contact: Avoid touching healthy plants after handling infected ones. If possible, work with healthy plants first and then move to infected plants to minimize transmission.  Crop rotation: Practice crop rotation by avoiding planting tomatoes or other susceptible Solanaceae family plants in the same area year after year. This helps break the virus's life cycle and reduces the risk of infection.  Resistant varieties: Consider planting tomato varieties that are resistant to TMV. These varieties have genetic traits that make them less susceptible to the virus and can help reduce the impact of the disease.
